bestBHT.bht: The preceding commandment, the Mosaic law, is abrogated due to its weakness and unprofitableness. It introduced and gave place to the Christian ordinance, but was unable to bring people into close fellowship with God. Its insufficiency to justify or sanctify individuals resulted in its disannulling. The establishment of the new and everlasting priesthood signifies the insufficiency and uselessness of the Mosaic law for salvation.

Henry Alford: There takes place an abrogation of the preceding commandment on account of its weakness and unprofitableness."
This commandment went before—not merely in time, but was an introduction to and gave way before the greater and final ordinance."
One of those coincidences which could hardly take place where there was not community of thought and diction.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: the legal ordinance introducing and giving place to the Christian
Albert Barnes: The Law which existed before in regard to the priesthood becomes now abrogated in consequence of the change which has been made in the priesthood.
It was not adapted to save man; it had not power to accomplish what was necessary to be done in human salvation.
It did not expiate guilt; it did not give peace to the conscience; it did not produce perfection.
Marvin Vincent: The fundamental idea is the doing away of something established.
The expression is indefinite, applying to any commandment which might be superseded.
It could not bring men into close fellowship with God.
John Calvin: For there is verily a disannulling, or abrogation, etc.
The Law is useless, when separated from Christ.

The Law had been promulgated long before David; but he was in possession of his kingdom when he proclaimed this prophecy respecting the appointment of a new priest; this new Law then annulled the former.
Archibald T. Robertson: A disannulling...in a legal sense of making void."
John Gill: Not the moral law; though what is here said of the commandment may be applied to that; that is sometimes called the commandment
the ceremonial law is meant, which is the commandment that respected the Levitical priesthood
the ceremonial law was weak; it could not expiate or atone for sin, in the sight of God; it could not remove the guilt of sin from the conscience
John Wesley: For there is implied in this new and everlasting priesthood, and in the new dispensation connected therewith, a disannulling of the preceding commandment..."
An abrogation of the Mosaic law.
For the weakness and unprofitableness thereof — For its insufficiency either to justify or to sanctify.

bhtAttempts.bht: The commandment referred to in this verse is the Mosaic law, which is now abrogated through the establishment of a new and everlasting priesthood. The Mosaic law, while introduced and given place to the Christian ordinance, was weak and unprofitable. It was unable to bring people into close fellowship with God, expiate guilt, or bring peace to the conscience. Therefore, this verse signifies the doing away of the Mosaic law, which was ineffective and useless in achieving what was necessary for human salvation.

The Mosaic law is abrogated in this passage, as it is weak and unprofitable. It introduced and gave way to the Christian ordinance, but it could not bring people into close fellowship with God or accomplish what was necessary for human salvation. Therefore, the new and everlasting priesthood signifies the disannulling of the preceding commandment, rendering it ineffective and useless in justifying or sanctifying individuals.

The Mosaic law, which is weak and unprofitable, is abrogated in this verse. It was an introduction to and gave way before the greater and final ordinance. The new and everlasting priesthood, associated with a new dispensation, implies the disannulling of the preceding commandment. The Mosaic law was ineffective for justifying or sanctifying individuals and could not bring them into close fellowship with God. Its weakness and unprofitableness rendered it useless for achieving salvation.

The abrogation of the preceding commandment, the Mosaic law, is highlighted in this passage. The commandment went before and made way for the greater and final ordinance of the Christian dispensation. The weakness and unprofitableness of the Mosaic law could not bring people into close fellowship with God, thus necessitating its disannulling. This commandment was insufficient to justify or sanctify individuals, revealing its uselessness and inability to accomplish what was necessary for salvation. Therefore, the establishment of the new and everlasting priesthood signifies the inadequacy of the Mosaic law.

The preceding commandment, the Mosaic law, is abrogated due to its weakness and unprofitableness. It introduced and gave place to the Christian ordinance, but was unable to bring people into close fellowship with God. Its insufficiency to justify or sanctify individuals resulted in its disannulling. The establishment of the new and everlasting priesthood signifies the insufficiency and uselessness of the Mosaic law for salvation.
